channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Thousands in Southern California told to evacuate as wind-fed wildfire spreads
item.description: The Mountain Fire, northwest of Los Angeles, destroyed dozens of homes and forced thousands of residents to flee as forecasters warned of the potential for “extreme and life-threatening” blazes.
item.content:encoded:
The Mountain Fire, northwest of Los Angeles, destroyed dozens of homes and forced thousands of residents to flee as forecasters warned of the potential for “extreme and life-threatening” blazes.

(Image credit: Ethan Swope)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Amazon ordered to let workers vote on unionizing -- for the 3rd time
item.description: A federal administrative law judge says Amazon interfered in the last election on unionization at its warehouse in Bessemer, Ala.
item.content:encoded:
A federal administrative law judge says Amazon interfered in the last election on unionization at its warehouse in Bessemer, Ala.

(Image credit: Patrick Fallon)
item.dc:creator: Alina Selyukh

item.title: Who's sending Trump back to the White House and why?
item.description:
In the days leading up to election night, news outlets across the country were predicting a historically close race, one that could take days to call.

But as election night progressed, it became clear former President Donald Trump was on a path to victory. So much so, that before anything was official, he thanked his supporters from his campaign headquarters in West Palm Beach.

And then, Wednesday morning at about 5:30, it became official when the Associated Press called Wisconsin for Trump. We're still awaiting final tallies, but it appears Trump is on track to win the popular vote for the first time.

Trump's agenda for a second term will be dissected over and over in the days ahead. Today, we break down how America sent him back to office --- how Trump won in 2024.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org
item.content:encoded:
In the days leading up to election night, news outlets across the country were predicting a historically close race, one that could take days to call.

But as election night progressed, it became clear former President Donald Trump was on a path to victory. So much so, that before anything was official, he thanked his supporters from his campaign headquarters in West Palm Beach.

And then, Wednesday morning at about 5:30, it became official when the Associated Press called Wisconsin for Trump. We're still awaiting final tallies, but it appears Trump is on track to win the popular vote for the first time.

Trump's agenda for a second term will be dissected over and over in the days ahead. Today, we break down how America sent him back to office --- how Trump won in 2024.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)

item.title: Where things stand in the 2024 election
item.description: Donald Trump will again take the White House, according to calls by the Associated Press in key states, and he appears to be on track to do so with full control of the political levers in Washington.
item.content:encoded:
Donald Trump will again take the White House, according to calls by the Associated Press in key states, and he appears to be on track to do so with full control of the political levers in Washington.

(Image credit: Ting Shen)
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: Germany's coalition government collapses as Chancellor Scholz fires his finance chief
item.description: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz has fired Finance Minister Christian Lindner, paving the way for a confidence vote by parliament in January that is expected to lead to early elections next March.
item.content:encoded:
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz has fired Finance Minister Christian Lindner, paving the way for a confidence vote by parliament in January that is expected to lead to early elections next March.

(Image credit: Markus Schreiber)
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: How personality trumped policy in this media election cycle
item.description: President-elect Trump has excelled at creating his own media image, from his earliest days as a real estate baron. His supporters find him entertaining and feisty, and even critics find it difficult not to talk about him.
item.content:encoded:
President-elect Trump has excelled at creating his own media image, from his earliest days as a real estate baron. His supporters find him entertaining and feisty, and even critics find it difficult not to talk about him.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Eric Deggans

item.title: Special counsel Jack Smith taking steps to wind down federal cases against Trump
item.description: Special counsel Jack Smith is taking steps to end both federal cases against Trump before the president-elect takes office, according to a source familiar with the Justice Department deliberations.
item.content:encoded:
Special counsel Jack Smith is taking steps to end both federal cases against Trump before the president-elect takes office, according to a source familiar with the Justice Department deliberations.

(Image credit: Drew Angerer)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: What’s the world saying about Trump’s win? Here are the leaders who’ve commented
item.description: Leaders from around the world congratulated Donald Trump on his presidential election victory, as governments prepare for his return to the White House and the potential impact that will have.
item.content:encoded:
Leaders from around the world congratulated Donald Trump on his presidential election victory, as governments prepare for his return to the White House and the potential impact that will have.

(Image credit: Leon Neal)
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Trump’s victory promises to shake up U.S. energy and climate policy, analysts and activists say
item.description: Despite Donald Trump’s focus on fossil fuels, his return to the White House won’t derail clean energy, analysts and activists say.
item.content:encoded:
Despite Donald Trump’s focus on fossil fuels, his return to the White House won’t derail clean energy, analysts and activists say.

(Image credit: Evan Vucci/AP)
item.dc:creator: Michael Copley

item.title: How health care could change under the new Trump administration
item.description: Trump's victory gives a broader platform to critics of federal health programs. Among other moves, he may try to weaken the Affordable Care Act and cut funding for Medicaid coverage.
item.content:encoded:
Trump's victory gives a broader platform to critics of federal health programs. Among other moves, he may try to weaken the Affordable Care Act and cut funding for Medicaid coverage.

(Image credit: Alex Brandon)
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Armour
